newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX front-month electricity up, back-months down.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX front-month electricity up, back-months down.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures for remainder of 1996 finished mostly higher Wednesday, but deferred contracts settled unchanged to lower in another thinly traded session.
Steady buying interest and firm physical prices in the western U.S. helped move the front-month contracts into the black, industry sources said.
The absence of Bonneville Power Administration in the spot market today gave support to short-term physical prices in the West, brokers and traders.
"That spooked a few people," said one Houston trader.
"We found some support for October COB (California-Oregon Border) at $15.60-$15.70," a New York futures broker added.
October COB settled up 35 cents at $16.10 per megawatt hour (MWh) after hitting a session low of $15.75.
November 1996 through January 1997 COB ended five to 30 cents higher. Other active back-month COB contracts finished 10-15 cents lower.
October Palo Verde (PV) settled up five cents at $16.80 per MWh after traded in a tight 10 cent range.
December 1996 and January 1997 PV futures ended five and 10 cents lower, without any trades.
Despite today's higher settlements, a lack of fresh fundamental news will likely keep the electricity complex in narrow trading.
"We'll see some sideways trading for a while," the Houston trader said.
NYMEX estimated 145 COB and 113 PV contracts were sold today.
